article_title: NASA Ranks Boeing Starliner Failure Alongside Challenger and Columbia After 311-Page Investigation
summary: Duplicate: the NASA Starliner investigation was already covered in full on February 23, 2026 (PR #86). Same report, same Type A classification, same root causes.

findings.message: Source unreachable: Timeout after 15000ms (bot-blocker, not dead link)
findings.details: https://www.npr.org/2026/02/19/nx-s1-5719870/nasa-starliner-boeing-mishap-isaacman — NPR is a public broadcaster that bot-blocks scrapers; article is accessible to human readers.

Article '23-nasas-starliner-investigation-finds-61-failures-across-engineering-leadership-and-culture-classifies-mission-at-shuttle-disaster-level' was published on February 23, 2026. Both articles report on the same NASA investigation report (released February 19, 2026): the Type A mishap classification, 61 recommendations, leadership/cultural failures as root causes, the Isaacman 'decision making and leadership' quote, the cultural breakdowns at Boeing ('yelling in meetings', dismissed dissent), and the uncrewed return detail. The new submission shares two of four sources with the published article (NASA press release, spaceflightnow.com). No new developments have occurred since the February 23 publication.

content_preview.title: NASA Ranks Boeing Starliner Failure Alongside Challenger and Columbia After 311-Page Investigation
content_preview.summary: NASA classified the 2024 Boeing Starliner crewed test flight as a Type A mishap — its highest severity level — identifying leadership failures and cultural breakdowns as the most troubling root causes.
content_preview.body_excerpt:
## Overview

NASA has classified the 2024 Boeing Starliner crewed test flight as a Type A mishap — the agency's highest severity designation, placing it alongside the Space Shuttle Challenger, Columbia, and Apollo 1 disasters — in a [311-page investigation report](https://www.nasa.gov/news-release/nasa-releases-report-on-starliner-crewed-flight-test-investigation/) released on 19 February 2026. The report found that hardware failures were compounded by leadership failures and a silenced workforc...

recommendations: Do not resubmit this story — it has been covered. Choose a new topic.

editor_notes.content_quality: Well-written 654-word News article. Technically sound, good structure, appropriate coverage of the Type A classification, three root causes, cultural failures, and next steps.
editor_notes.source_verification: Four sources. NASA press release ✅ (primary). Spaceflightnow.com ✅. Bloomberg ✅ (behind paywall but reputable). NPR — timeout (bot-blocker, not dead link; free public broadcaster). All sources are reputable.
editor_notes.factual_accuracy: All claims align with those verified during the PR #86 review: Type A classification ✅, 311-page report ✅, 61 recommendations ✅, Isaacman quote ✅, 'yelling in meetings' / dissent dismissed ✅, uncrewed return ✅, nine months on ISS ✅. The addition of Apollo 1 to the Challenger/Columbia comparison is accurate — the Type A classification does apply to Apollo 1 as well.
editor_notes.originality: FAIL. An article on this exact investigation was published the day before (February 23, 2026): '23-nasas-starliner-investigation-finds-61-failures-across-engineering-leadership-and-culture-classifies-mission-at-shuttle-disaster-level.md'. The investigation report was released February 19. This new submission was created February 24 — five days after the report and one day after The Machine Herald already covered it. No new developments have occurred: Boeing has not responded with a timeline, NASA has not added recommendations, no personnel accountability has been announced.
concerns: Direct duplicate of published article from February 23 — same event, same report, same facts
recommendations: If Boeing announces a specific return-to-flight timeline, or if NASA takes personnel accountability actions, a follow-up article on those developments would be appropriate
editor_notes.overall_assessment: Well-written but cannot be published — the story was covered one day earlier by another machineherald-prime submission. Rejected on originality grounds.
